moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. Nc3 d5 4. cxd5 Nxd:
This is a fairly standard - the Exchange Variation of the Grünfeld Defence https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gr%C3%BCnfeld_Defence#Exchange_Variation:_4.cxd5_Nxd5_5.e4
White's move order though is slightly strange - I played 9. 0-0 instead of 9. Be3 to avoid black exchanging pawns on d4 and then throwing in a queen check on a5. Black's next is an attempt to take advantage of this.
moves.9... Qc7: Although this move is the third most popular, according to the World Database on Gameknot, - after Nc6 and cxd4 - it also scores the best. Black now threatens to take on d4, discovering an attack on the Bc4.
moves.10. d5: 10. Bf4 e5 11. Bxe5 Bxe5 12. dxe5 Qxe5 13. Bd5 seems to be the best way forward for white.
moves.11. f4: Keeping the Nd7 out of e5. Bf4 or Rb1 has been played in this position previously.
moves.11... Nb6: So the knight comes out this way instead.
moves.14... Bxe2: He takes. I was rather expecting him to retreat of c8, but this seems adequate.
moves.17. Kh1: Considering what happens later, maybe Kh2 was better.
moves.18. Qe3: I protect. Now 18....Na4 is met with Ba3 with complications.
moves.18... Rd7: So now he is threatening Na4
moves.19... Rfd8: He doubles on the d file.
moves.20. Ra3: this was probably a mistake. By over-protecting c3, I release the Bb2 and/or the Qe3 for other duties.
moves.29... Qxa4: He takes. he is now threatening Rxf5 and if I recapture, Qd1+ is winning for him.
moves.30... Qc6: Queen comes back to protect his king-side
moves.31. Bc1: So my bishop heads towards the new war-zone.
moves.31... Kh8: By breaking the pin, black is now threatening to take on f5.
moves.32. Bh6: But now if he takes, he gets mated.
moves.32... Rf7: I now lay a trap which he falls into.
moves.33. e6: He sees the chance to take my queen.
moves.33... Bd6: He falls into the trap. 33.....Rf6 is correct and good.
moves.34... Bxg3+: He takes my queen with check.
moves.35... Qc7+: He has to play this to stop my pawn queening.
moves.36... Qxf7: He takes. Right, white to play and win!
moves.37. Be4: A blunder! 37. Bg4 was the only way to win.
moves.37... Qc7: Now the pin stops the mate on f8.
moves.38... Nd7: But now there is no mate.
moves.39. Rf7: A final blunder in a lost position.
